A hydrothermal technique was employed in order to produce a novel coordination polymer [Co0.42Ni0.40Zn0.68(btc)(H2O)6] (1). The complex (1) was characterized by elemental analysis, and FT-IR spectroscopy; and its structure was determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD). Alumina-supported Co–Ni–Zn and silica catalysts were prepared by thermal decomposition of respective inorganic precursors (fabricated or synthesized catalysts) and through impregnation method as reference catalysts. The evaluation of catalytic activity of these catalysts was carried out at a fixed bed reactor for Fischer–Tropsch synthesis. The performance of the synthesized catalysts was much better than the catalysts which were produced by the impregnation procedure, those that were characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), XRD, and BET specific surface area.

Introduction

Fischer–Tropsch synthesis (FTS) is a catalytic polymerization reaction through which clean fuels can be produced from natural gas, biomass and coal [1–3]. Catalysts based on cobalt, nickel, iron and ruthenium are considered efficient compounds for hydrogenation of carbon monoxide [4–6] despite the fact that group VIII transition metals catalyze the FTS.

Owing to their low water–gas shift activity, long life and high selectivity into aliphatic hydrocarbons [7, 8], cobalt-based catalysts are particularly useful for the FTS. Promoters have a number of advantages for Co-based catalysts in the FTS; for example, Rytter et al. [9] found that nickel deeply affects the catalytic activity and can be used as a promoter of reduction and activity (with loading > 5 wt%). Ishihara et al. [10, 11] proved that an alloy of cobalt and nickel reinforces hydrogen adsorption, and leads to an increase in the catalytic activity. With regard to these results and other investigations [12, 13], nickel can be employed as a promoter in FTS. In addition, another possible promoter for cobalt-based catalysts is zinc, which can reduce cobalt–support interaction, thereby affecting cobalt reducibility [14, 15].

The design of synthetic procedures for catalysts that are suitable for FTS is technologically very important. An appropriate method used in applying inorganic complexes to produce mixed metal oxides exhibits some advantages such as smaller particle sizes, higher surface area and homogenous dispersion of metals [16–21]. In this work, a new inorganic complex [Co0.42Ni0.40Zn0.68(btc)(H2O)6] was prepared and the complex was used for the fabrication of inorganic precursors. Then, the mixed metal oxides resulting from thermal decomposition of inorganic precursors were evaluated for catalytic activity in FTS, and were compared with reference catalysts which were generated by the impregnation procedure; and the physicochemical characterizations were determined by Brunauer–Emmett–Teller method (BET), X-ray diffraction (XRD) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM).

ExperimentalMaterials and Instruments

All purchased chemicals and solvents were of reagent grade and were used without further purification; elemental analyses were carried out by using a Leco, CHNS-932 elemental analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were measured with Perkin Elmer (spectrum two) spectrophotometer as KBr disks in the 4000–400 cm−1 range, and simultaneous thermal analysis (STA) was made by usingRheometric Scientific ARES, at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. Powder diffraction data were recorded on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE the 2θ range from 10° to 80°, and the morphology of the catalysts was studied on MIRA3 TESCANFE SEM,operatingwith an accelerating voltage of 15 kV. The BET surface areas of the samples were measured by N2 physi-sorption using anASAP 2020 apparatus. Each sample was degassed under nitrogen atmosphere at 350 °C for 4 h. The images were recorded with transmission electron microscope (TEM) Philips CM120 with a LaB6 cathode at acceleration voltage 120 kV. TEM is equipped with a CCD camera Olympus Veleta. Powdered samples were prepared by dispersing in water under ultrasonic treatment. Drop of suspension was evaporated on cooper grid with carbon film. H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were carried out using a NanoSORD NS91 (made by Sensiran Co., Iran) apparatus. H2-TPR experiments were conducted on 50 mg of each catalyst placed in a U-shaped quartz reactor. Prior to each TPR run, the catalyst was degassed in a flow of 10 sccmAr at 300 °C for 1 h, and it was cooled down to room temperature under the same atmosphere. The sample was then reduced by 10 sccm of 5.0% H2/Ar mixture while the temperature was raised to 900 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1.

Synthesis of Complex 1

1,3,5-Benzenetricarboxylic acid (105 mg, 0.5 mmol) was dissolved in 10 ml of distilled water, followed by addition of NaOH (40 mg, 1 mmol). Then it was stirred 30 min at room temperature. An aqueous solution of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (291 mg, 1.0 mmol), Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O (290 mg, 1 mmol) and Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (297 mg, 1.0 mmol) was appended to the above-mentioned solution and was stirred 30 min at room temperature. The resulting solution was placed in a Parr-Teflon lined stainless steel vessel. It was sealed and heated to 130 °C for 3 days and then cooled to the room temperature. Colorless crystals of 1 were obtained by filtration and they were dried in air. The yield was 75%. Anal. Calc. for C9H15Co0.42Ni0.40O12.06Zn0.68: C, 8.01; H, 1.12. Found: C, 8.04; H, 1.08%.

X-ray Structure Determination

Single crystal of approximate dimensions 0.04 × 0.06 × 0.37 mm for complex 1 was used for the determination of crystal structure on SuperNova diffractometer equipped with mirror monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). A total of 11,665 reflections were collected in the range of 3.39°<θ < 29.71° at 95 (10) K, of which 3363 independent ones [R(int) = 0.0206] were used. The crystal structure was solved by direct methods with the Superflip program [22] and was refined by full-matrix least squares on F2 using the program Jana 2006 [23]. All hydrogen atoms present in the structure model were discernible in difference Fourier maps and could be refined to reasonable geometry; nevertheless, hydrogen atoms attached to carbon were constraint at geometrically expected positions. Positions of water hydrogen atoms were refined using an O–H bond restraint 0.88 Å with s.u. 0.001, and H–O–H angle restraint 105° with s.u. 1.0. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined using harmonic refinement, while for hydrogen atoms isotropic ADPs were used with Uiso(H) = 1.2Ueq(C, O). The crystallographic dataare summarized in Table 1.

The mixed site disorder was observed in the structure, and the coordinates and ADPs of the mixed site atoms were made equal. Since the refinement of the metal ratios was not possible due to the electronic similarities of three present metals, the ratio determined by microprobe analysis was used instead, and because the structure crystallized in non-centrosymmetric space group, the Flack parameter was refined with a resulting value of 0.460 (8).

Synthesis of [Co<sub>0.42</sub>Ni<sub>0.40</sub>Zn<sub>0.68</sub> (btc)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>6</sub>]/SiO<sub>2</sub> Precursor

To prepare [Co0.42Ni0.40Zn0.68 (btc)(H2O)6]/SiO2 precursor, 0.6 g silica was added to an aqueous solution containing 5.2 g of the complex 1. The mixture was stirred and evaporated at 60 °C in a rota-evaporator for 5 h. The resulting precipitate was filtrated and then it was dried in an oven at 120 °C for 12 h.

Synthesis of Silica-Supported Cobalt–Nickel–Zinc Catalyst, Co–Ni–Zn/SiO<sub>2</sub>

The cobalt–nickel–zinc catalyst was prepared by calcinating [Co0.42Ni0.40Zn0.68 (btc)(H2O)6]/SiO2 precursor at 600 °C at the atmosphere of static air in an electric furnacemaintaining the temperature for 6 h.

Synthesis of [Co<sub>0.42</sub>Ni<sub>0.40</sub>Zn<sub>0.68</sub> (btc)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>6</sub>]/Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> Precursor

The [Co0.42Ni0.40Zn0.68 (btc)(H2O)6]/Al2O3 precursor was obtained by mixing 0.6 g of alumina with an aqueous solution containing 5.2 g of the complex 1. The suspension was stirred and aged at 60 °C in a rota-evaporator for 5 h. The final mixture was filtrated and dried in an oven at 120 °C for 12 h.

Synthesis of Alumina-Supported Cobalt–Nickel–Zinc Catalyst, Co–Ni–Zn/Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>

The [Co0.42Ni0.40Zn0.68 (btc)(H2O)6]/Al2O3 was calcined at 600 °C in an electric furnaceat the atmosphere of static air for 6 h.

Preparation of Reference Catalysts

The silica- or alumina-supported Co–Ni–Zn reference catalysts werepreparedusing the impregnation method. The support (silica or alumina) wasimpregnated by using an aqueous solution consisting of nickel nitrate, cobalt nitrate and zinc nitrate. The suspension was stirred and heated at 60 °C in a rota-evaporator and it was kept at this temperature for 5 h. After that, the resulting mixture was filtrated and dried in an oven at 120 °C for 12 h, and the precursor was calcined at 600 °C for 5 h.

Catalytic Activity Measurements

The catalytic performances of the catalysts for the Fischer–Tropsch reaction were carried out in a fixed bed micro reactor operating at the atmospheric pressure. The reactor tube was made of stainless steel with an internal diameter of 1.7 cm. In each run, 0.8 g of the catalyst was loaded to the reactor and reduced in a mixture of hydrogen/nitrogen gas (with a flow rate of 30 mL min−1 for each gas) at 400 °C for 8 h. The N2/H2 was then replaced for the synthesis gas H2/CO (2:1), and the Fischer–Tropsch reaction was carried out at the temperature range of 200–300 °C and GHSV = 2700 h−1. The gas chromatograph (Thermo ONIX UNICAM PROGC+), equipped with sample loop, two thermal conductivity detectors (TCD) and one flame ionization detector (FID), was employed for online analysis of the reactant and product streams. The TCD was used for the analysis of H2 and CO, and the analysis of hydrocarbons was carried out by FID. The contents of the sample loop were automatically injected into a capillary column, and each run of GC analysis lasted more than 30 min. Results and DiscussionCharacterization of the ComplexCrystal Structure

The complex 1, which is a coordination polymer with two symmetry-distinct mixed-sites metal centers containing cobalt(II), nickel(II) and zinc(II) cations,crystalizes in the monoclinic system with the non-centrosymmetric space group C2. As shown in Fig. 1, four oxygen atoms from water molecules and two oxygen atoms from carboxylate groups surround each metal center .The Co(II), Ni(II) and Zn(II) ions are six-coordinated in a distorted octahedral geometry, and all bond distances and bond angles correspond well with values found in other cobalt(II), nickel(II) and zinc(II) complexes [24–26]. Selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in Table 2.

Several inter-molecular and intra-molecular hydrogen bonds stabilize the crystal structure (Fig. 2). The coordinated water molecules act as donors in hydrogen bonds, whereas oxygen atoms of carboxylate groups and those of other water molecules are used as the acceptors of the bond. For further details on hydrogen bonding, refer to Table 3.

The metallic center which is located at a twofold crystallographic axis coordinates carboxylate in a bidentate mode, whereas the center that is located at a general symmetry position connects two carboxylates by two μ\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\mu$$\end{document}-oxo bridges (Fig. 3.) creating a zig-zag polymeric chain. The 3D packing of the structure is shown in Fig. 4.

FT-IR Spectrum

The FT-IR spectrum of 1 (Fig. 5) displays a broad band at 3456 cm−1 which is assigned to the stretching vibrations of the coordinated water molecules. The strong band which is observed at 1615 cm−1 is the result of deprotonation of carboxyl groups [27, 28], and the band at 3195 cm−1 is assigned to C–H stretching vibration of the benzene ring [29]. Lack of vibrations at the 1700 cm−1 indicates that the carboxylic groups are fully deprotonated. The anti-symmetric νa(COO) stretching vibrations of the carboxylate groups appear at 1522 and 1472 cm−1, while the symmetric stretching, νs(COO), emerges at 1372 and 1434 cm−1. The frequency differences (Δν\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$${\Delta }{\upnu }$$\end{document}) are 150 and 38 cm−1 indicating the presence of monodentate and bidentate coordination mode of the carboxylate groups to the metallic centers, respectively [30]. The band which appears at 719 cm−1 belongs to the δ(COO) vibration.

Thermal Analysis

The thermal stability of complex 1 was investigated by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), Fig. 6. Two weight losses at the temperature region of 80–260 °C are brought about by eliminating the water molecules, with a total weight loss of about 26.6%\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\%$$\end{document} (calcd. 26.4%\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\%$$\end{document}). The two ultimate steps of weight losses occur while the temperature is being increased to 540 °C, and they are attributed to the decomposition of H3btc ligands. No further weight loss occurs until 800 °C indicating an inorganic residuum in the form of metal oxides.

Further evaluationof the complex thermal behavior was conducted by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) (Fig. 6). Multiple endo- and exo-thermic effects in the DSC curve matched TGA results. The endothermic peak observed at the temperature region of 80–260 °C is related to the removal of coordinated water molecules, and two exothermic peaks at the temperature region 400–540 °C are attributed to successiveburning of organic parts.

Catalysts CharacterizationFT-IR Spectrum

The FT-IR spectra of the silica- and alumina-supported Co–Ni–Zn synthesized catalysts are illustrated in Fig. 7. In the FT-IR spectrum of Co–Ni–Zn/SiO2 catalyst, the broad bond at 3421 cm−1 belongs to the OH stretching mode of physically adsorbed water; in addition, the H–OH bending vibration appears at 1610 cm−1 [31]. The strong band at 909 cm−1 is assigned to the asymmetric stretching mode of Si–O–Si, and the bands observed at 468, 581and 671 cm−1 are imputed to the stretching vibrations of Ni–O, Zn–O and Co–O, respectively [32–34].

In the FT-IR spectrum of alumina-supported Co–Ni–Zn catalyst, the OH stretching vibration and the H–OH bending mode of physically adsorbed water appear at 3415 and 1618 cm−1, respectively. The bending vibration of Al–O–Al emerges at 1117 cm−1, and the stretching modes of Ni–O, Zn–O and Co–O appear at 450, 583and 672 cm−1, respectively.

X-ray Powder Diffraction

The Co–Ni–Zn catalysts obtained through calcination of inorganic precursors were characterized by X-ray powder diffraction. The X-ray diffractograms of the silica- and alumina-supported Co–Ni–Zn synthesized catalysts have been shown in Fig. 8. The identified phases for both synthesized Co–Ni–Zn catalysts were similar, and contained Ni0.8Zn0.2O and NiO (characteristic peaks for their overlap at 2Ɵ = 37.2°, 43.3°, 62.5°, 74.7°, 78.8°), ZnO (characteristic peaks at 2θ = 31.9°, 34.7°, 47.5°, 62.5°, 68.7°), ZnCo2O4 (characteristic peaks at 2θ = 16.1°, 31.9°, 37.2°, 56.5°, 59.3°, 65.1°, 74.7°), Co3O4 (characteristic peaks at 2θ = 31.9°, 37.2°, 56.5°, 59.3°, 65.1°) and NiCo2O4 (characteristic peaks at 2θ = 20.9°, 31.9°, 37.2°, 56.5°, 59.3°, 65.1°).

The diffractograms of reference catalysts constructed by impregnation method have been illustrated in Fig. 9. Characteristic peaks of NiCo2O4 at 2θ = 31.2°, 37.2°, 44.8°, 55.7°, 59.3°, 65.1° are observed; the peaks observed at 2θ = 19.1°, 31.2°, 37.2°, 44.8°, 55.7°, 59.3°, 65.1° are related to overlapping of phases Co3O4 and ZnCo2O4.

Scanning Electron Microscopy

The morphology of the synthesized and reference catalysts was investigated by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and their SEM micrographs have been shown in Figs. 10 and 11, respectively. The morphological properties of the synthesized catalysts and those of reference catalysts are different, and they have smaller particle sizes and less agglomeration for the fabricated catalysts.

Brunauer–Emmett–Teller

Textural properties of the catalysts constructed by thermal decomposition of inorganic precursor and those of the reference catalysts prepared by the impregnation method have been displayed in Table 4. As observed in Table 4, synthesized catalysts have higher surface areas in comparison to reference catalysts. These results were in agreement with the SEM observation which showed the particle sizes of the fabricated catalysts were less than those of the reference catalysts.

Transmission Electron Microscopy

The TEM images of the synthesized and reference catalysts are displayed in Fig. S1. The average crystallite sizes were respectively 15 and 22 nm for the fabricated catalysts with the SiO2 and Al2O3 support, while for the reference catalysts these values were 38 and 40 nm. This result shows that preparation of Co–Ni–Zn catalysts via thermal decomposition of inorganic precursors yields smaller crystallite sizes.

Reducibility Studies (H<sub>2</sub>-TPR)

The H2-TPR profiles of the synthesized catalysts have been shown in Fig. S2. The reduction peak observed in the range of 300–420 °C corresponds to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO, NiCo2O4 to NiCoO2 and NiO to Ni. At this temperature region, Co3+ and Zn2+ of ZnCoO4 phase were reduced to Co2+ and Zn0, respectively. For the NiCoO2, the broad peak at 420–635 °C is assigned to co-reduction of Co2+ to Co0 and Ni2+ to Ni0, Additionally, the reduction of CoO to Co0 occurred at the same temperature range. The reduction peak around 660 °C corresponds to the reduction of ZnO to Zn0 [35–42].

The H2-TPR profiles of both reference catalysts reveal multiple overlapping peaks because of different reduction steps (Fig. S3). It can be seen that both reference catalysts have the same reduction peaks at 300 to 400 °C and 400–700 °C, and this is related to the reduction of Co3O4, NiCo2O4 and ZnCoO4 phases, like synthesized catalysts. According to TPR and XRD results, one point that makes synthesized catalysts different from reference catalysts is the existence of NiO and ZnO phases in the synthesized catalysts. In fact, these phases serve as promoters in the catalysts. The ZnO phase reduces cobalt-support interaction and affects cobalt reducibility; furthermore, the NiO phase amplifies the hydrogen adsorption. Hence, these phases affect catalyst activity and improve the catalytic activity of synthesized catalysts.

Catalytic Performance

Hydrogenation of carbon monoxide at the presence of the synthesized and reference catalysts was conducted at the atmospheric pressureat the temperature range 200–300 °C with H2/CO ratio of 2.

As shown in Fig. 12, the CO conversion of the catalysts increases with the temperature, and the CO conversion of the synthesized Co–Ni–Zn/SiO2 and –Al2O3 catalysts is higher in comparison to the reference catalysts at all studied temperatures.

The catalytic performance of the catalysts that is prepared by different procedures grows with an increase in temperature from 200 to 300 °C (Figs. 13, 14). While the selectivity to the olefin and paraffin is reduced with an increase in temperature, the methane selectivities of both constructed and reference catalysts grow. The results revealed that the optimal operating temperature of the catalysts is 260 °C. At this temperature, the Co–Ni–Zn/SiO2 and Co–Ni–Zn/Al2O3 synthesized catalysts, prepared by thermal decomposition of inorganic precursor, have higher selectivity to light olefin products and lower methane selectivity. Moreover, the paraffin selectivity is favorable at the optimum temperature. Selectivity to C2H4 is 46% and 40% for silica and alumina supported, respectively. In addition, propylene selectivity of synthesized catalysts is about 16%. The selectivity into paraffin (C2–C3) of synthesized catalyst obtains about 19% and 17% for silica and alumina supported, respectively. As the data show, the synthesized catalysts have acceptable activity in FT reaction due to the catalyst physicochemical features. It can be seen that from SEM results of synthesized catalysts, these catalysts have low degree of agglomeration and small particle sizes, which is in good agreement with the results obtained from XRD. Moreover, the synthesized catalysts have high surface area. According to the explained catalysts feature, it can be concluded that the catalyst physicochemical features affect the catalysts activity. Comparing both synthesized catalysts, it can be concluded that the catalytic performance of Co–Ni–Zn/SiO2 is slightly better than alumina-supported Co–Ni–Zn catalyst. On the other hand, in both reference catalysts, methane selectivity is higher compared to the fabricated catalysts, and the production amount of olefins and paraffins is lower. All these data reveal that catalysts production through thermal decomposition of inorganic precursors based on complex 1 is a promising procedure due to good active phase dispersion, small particle size, low degree of agglomeration and formation of promoter phases.

Stability Test

The stability (Fig. 15) of the constructed catalysts was studied at 260 °C, and that of the reference catalysts was evaluated at 300 °C because they display the maximum CO conversion at this temperature. The catalysts prepared by thermal decomposition were stable for 10 h atoptimal operating temperature (260 °C). The stability test of the constructed catalysts was continued for 30 h, and only a slight decrease in the activity of the catalysts was observed. The activity of the reference catalysts was relatively constant for 7 h, and during the following 30 h, the activity decreased faster than for the synthesized catalysts.

Conclusion

The Co–Ni–Zn mixed metal catalysts were produced by thermal decomposition of their inorganic precursors and were compared with the reference catalysts prepared by the impregnation method. The different preparation procedure causes smaller particle size, higher surface area and lower agglomeration of the catalysts fabricated by thermal decomposition. The catalytic performance tests of both types of catalysts were carried out at the temperature range 200–300 °C with H2:CO ratio of 2:1. The results show higher selectivity to desirable products and better stability for the fabricated catalysts.

users.IntroductionFischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) is a catalytic polymerization reaction through which clean fuels can be produced from natural gas, biomass and coal [1-3]. Catalysts based on cobalt, nickel, iron and ruthenium are considered efficient compounds for hydrogenation of carbon monoxide [4-6] despite the fact that group VIII transition metals catalyze the FTS.Owing to their low water-gas shift activity, long life and high selectivity into aliphatic hydrocarbons [7, 8], cobalt-based catalysts are particularly useful for the FTS. Promoters have a number of advantages for Co-based catalysts in the FTS; for example, Rytter et al. [9] found that nickel deeply affects the catalytic activity and can be used as a promoter of reduction and activity (with loading>5 wt%). Ishihara et al. [10, 11] proved that an alloy of cobalt and nickel reinforces hydrogen adsorption, and leads to an increase in the catalytic activity. With regard to these results and other investigations [12, 13], nickel can be employed as a promoter in FTS. In addition, another possible promoter for cobalt-based catalysts is zinc, which can reduce cobalt-support interaction, thereby affecting cobalt reducibility [14, 15].The design of synthetic procedures for catalysts that are suitable for FTS is technologically very important. An appropriate method used in applying inorganic complexes to produce mixed metal oxides exhibits some advantages such as smaller particle sizes, higher surface area and homogenous dispersion of metals [16-21]. In this work, a new inorganic complex [Co0.42Ni0.40Zn0.68(btc)(H2O)6] was prepared and the complex was used for the fabrication of inorganic precursors. Then, the mixed metal oxides resulting from thermal decomposition of inorganic precursors were evaluated for catalytic activity in FTS, and were compared with reference catalysts which were generated by the impregnation procedure; and the physicochemical characterizations were determined by Brunauer-Emmett-Teller method (BET), X-ray diffraction (XRD) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM).ExperimentalMaterials and InstrumentsAll purchased chemicals and solvents were of reagent grade and were used without further purification; elemental analyses were carried out by using a Leco, CHNS-932 elemental analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were measured with Perkin Elmer (spectrum two) spectrophotometer as KBr disks in the 4000-400 cm-1 range, and simultaneous thermal analysis (STA) was made by usingRheometric Scientific ARES, at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. Powder diffraction data were recorded on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE the 2θ range from 10° to 80°, and the morphology of the catalysts was studied on MIRA3 TESCANFE SEM,operatingwith an accelerating voltage of 15 kV. The BET surface areas of the samples were measured by N2 physi-sorption using anASAP 2020 apparatus. Each sample was degassed under nitrogen atmosphere at 350 °C for 4 h. The images were recorded with transmission electron microscope (TEM) Philips CM120 with a LaB6 cathode at acceleration voltage 120 kV. TEM is equipped with a CCD camera Olympus Veleta. Powdered samples were prepared by dispersing in water under ultrasonic treatment. Drop of suspension was evaporated on cooper grid with carbon film. H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were carried out using a NanoSORD NS91 (made by Sensiran Co., Iran) apparatus. H2-TPR experiments were conducted on 50 mg of each catalyst placed in a U-shaped quartz reactor. Prior to each TPR run, the catalyst was degassed in a flow of 10 sccmAr at 300 °C for 1 h, and it was cooled down to room temperature under the same atmosphere. The sample was then reduced by 10 sccm of 5.0% H2/Ar mixture while the temperature was raised to 900 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1.Synthesis of Complex 11,3,5-Benzenetricarboxylic acid (105 mg, 0.5 mmol) was dissolved in 10 ml of distilled water, followed by addition of NaOH (40 mg, 1 mmol). Then it was stirred 30 min at room temperature. An aqueous solution of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (291 mg, 1.0 mmol), Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O (290 mg, 1 mmol) and Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (297 mg, 1.0 mmol) was appended to the above-mentioned solution and was stirred 30 min at room temperature. The resulting solution was placed in a Parr-Teflon lined stainless steel vessel. It was sealed and heated to 130 °C for 3 days and then cooled to the room temperature. Colorless crystals of 1 were obtained by filtration and they were dried in air. The yield was 75%. Anal. Calc. for C9H15Co0.42Ni0.40O12.06Zn0.68: C, 8.01; H, 1.12. Found: C, 8.04; H, 1.08%.X-ray Structure DeterminationSingle crystal of approximate dimensions 0.04×0.06×0.37 mm for complex 1 was used for the determination of crystal structure on SuperNova diffractometer equipped with mirror monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ=0.71073 Å). A total of 11,665 reflections were collected in the range of 3.39°<θ<29.71° at 95 (10) K, of which 3363 independent ones [R(int)=0.0206] were used. The crystal structure was solved by direct methods with the Superflip program [22] and was refined by full-matrix least squares on F2 using the program Jana 2006 [23]. All hydrogen atoms present in the structure model were discernible in difference Fourier maps and could be refined to reasonable geometry; nevertheless, hydrogen atoms attached to carbon were constraint at geometrically expected positions. Positions of water hydrogen atoms were refined using an O-H bond restraint 0.88 Å with s.u. 0.001, and H-O-H angle restraint 105° with s.u. 1.0. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined using harmonic refinement, while for hydrogen atoms isotropic ADPs were used with Uiso(H)=1.2Ueq(C, O). The crystallographic dataare summarized in Table 1.The mixed site disorder was observed in the structure, and the coordinates and ADPs of the mixed site atoms were made equal. Since the refinement of the metal ratios was not possible due to the electronic similarities of three present metals, the ratio determined by microprobe analysis was used instead, and because the structure crystallized in non-centrosymmetric space group, the Flack parameter was refined with a resulting value of 0.460 (8).Synthesis of [Co0.42Ni0.40Zn0.68 (btc)(H2O)6]/SiO2 PrecursorTo prepare [Co0.42Ni0.40Zn0.68 (btc)(H2O)6]/SiO2 precursor, 0.6 g silica was added to an aqueous solution containing 5.2 g of the complex 1. The mixture was stirred and evaporated at 60 °C in a rota-evaporator for 5 h. The resulting precipitate was filtrated and then it was dried in an oven at 120 °C for 12 h.Synthesis of Silica-Supported Cobalt-Nickel-Zinc Catalyst, Co-Ni-Zn/SiO2The cobalt-nickel-zinc catalyst was prepared by calcinating [Co0.42Ni0.40Zn0.68 (btc)(H2O)6]/SiO2 precursor at 600 °C at the atmosphere of static air in an electric furnacemaintaining the temperature for 6 h.Synthesis of [Co0.42Ni0.40Zn0.68 (btc)(H2O)6]/Al2O3 PrecursorThe [Co0.42Ni0.40Zn0.68 (btc)(H2O)6]/Al2O3 precursor was obtained by mixing 0.6 g of alumina with an aqueous solution containing 5.2 g of the complex 1. The suspension was stirred and aged at 60 °C in a rota-evaporator for 5 h. The final mixture was filtrated and dried in an oven at 120 °C for 12 h.Synthesis of Alumina-Supported Cobalt-Nickel-Zinc Catalyst, Co-Ni-Zn/Al2O3The [Co0.42Ni0.40Zn0.68 (btc)(H2O)6]/Al2O3 was calcined at 600 °C in an electric furnaceat the atmosphere of static air for 6 h.Preparation of Reference CatalystsThe silica- or alumina-supported Co-Ni-Zn reference catalysts werepreparedusing the impregnation method. The support (silica or alumina) wasimpregnated by using an aqueous solution consisting of nickel nitrate, cobalt nitrate and zinc nitrate. The suspension was stirred and heated at 60 °C in a rota-evaporator and it was kept at this temperature for 5 h. After that, the resulting mixture was filtrated and dried in an oven at 120 °C for 12 h, and the precursor was calcined at 600 °C for 5 h.Catalytic Activity MeasurementsThe catalytic performances of the catalysts for the Fischer-Tropsch reaction were carried out in a fixed bed micro reactor operating at the atmospheric pressure. The reactor tube was made of stainless steel with an internal diameter of 1.7 cm. In each run, 0.8 g of the catalyst was loaded to the reactor and reduced in a mixture of hydrogen/nitrogen gas (with a flow rate of 30 mL min-1 for each gas) at 400 °C for 8 h. The N2/H2 was then replaced for the synthesis gas H2/CO (2:1), and the Fischer-Tropsch reaction was carried out at the temperature range of 200-300 °C and GHSV=2700 h-1. The gas chromatograph (Thermo ONIX UNICAM PROGC+), equipped with sample loop, two thermal conductivity detectors (TCD) and one flame ionization detector (FID), was employed for online analysis of the reactant and product streams. The TCD was used for the analysis of H2 and CO, and the analysis of hydrocarbons was carried out by FID. The contents of the sample loop were automatically injected into a capillary column, and each run of GC analysis lasted more than 30 min. As shown in Fig. 1, four oxygen atoms from water molecules and two oxygen atoms from carboxylate groups surround each metal center .The Co(II), Ni(II) and Zn(II) ions are six-coordinated in a distorted octahedral geometry, and all bond distances and bond angles correspond well with values found in other cobalt(II), nickel(II) and zinc(II) complexes [24-26]. Selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in Table 2.Several inter-molecular and intra-molecular hydrogen bonds stabilize the crystal structure (Fig. 2). The coordinated water molecules act as donors in hydrogen bonds, whereas oxygen atoms of carboxylate groups and those of other water molecules are used as the acceptors of the bond. For further details on hydrogen bonding, refer to Table 3.The metallic center which is located at a twofold crystallographic axis coordinates carboxylate in a bidentate mode, whereas the center that is located at a general symmetry position connects two carboxylates by two μ\documentclass[12pt]{minimal}     \usepackage{amsmath}     \usepackage{wasysym}     \usepackage{amsfonts}     \usepackage{amssymb}     \usepackage{amsbsy}     \usepackage{mathrsfs}     \usepackage{upgreek}     \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt}     \begin{document}$$\mu$$\end{document}-oxo bridges (Fig. 3.) creating a zig-zag polymeric chain. The 3D packing of the structure is shown in Fig. 4.FT-IR SpectrumThe FT-IR spectrum of 1 (Fig. 5) displays a broad band at 3456 cm-1 which is assigned to the stretching vibrations of the coordinated water molecules. The strong band which is observed at 1615 cm-1 is the result of deprotonation of carboxyl groups [27, 28], and the band at 3195 cm-1 is assigned to C-H stretching vibration of the benzene ring [29]. Lack of vibrations at the 1700 cm-1 indicates that the carboxylic groups are fully deprotonated. The anti-symmetric νa(COO) stretching vibrations of the carboxylate groups appear at 1522 and 1472 cm-1, while the symmetric stretching, νs(COO), emerges at 1372 and 1434 cm-1. The frequency differences (Δν\documentclass[12pt]{minimal}     \usepackage{amsmath}     \usepackage{wasysym}     \usepackage{amsfonts}     \usepackage{amssymb}     \usepackage{amsbsy}     \usepackage{mathrsfs}     \usepackage{upgreek}     \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt}     \begin{document}$${\Delta }{\upnu }$$\end{document}) are 150 and 38 cm-1 indicating the presence of monodentate and bidentate coordination mode of the carboxylate groups to the metallic centers, respectively [30]. The band which appears at 719 cm-1 belongs to the δ(COO) vibration.Thermal AnalysisThe thermal stability of complex 1 was investigated by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), Fig. 6. Two weight losses at the temperature region of 80-260 °C are brought about by eliminating the water molecules, with a total weight loss of about 26.6%\documentclass[12pt]{minimal}     \usepackage{amsmath}     \usepackage{wasysym}     \usepackage{amsfonts}     \usepackage{amssymb}     \usepackage{amsbsy}     \usepackage{mathrsfs}     \usepackage{upgreek}     \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt}     \begin{document}$$\%$$\end{document} (calcd. 26.4%\documentclass[12pt]{minimal}     \usepackage{amsmath}     \usepackage{wasysym}     \usepackage{amsfonts}     \usepackage{amssymb}     \usepackage{amsbsy}     \usepackage{mathrsfs}     \usepackage{upgreek}     \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt}     \begin{document}$$\%$$\end{document}). The two ultimate steps of weight losses occur while the temperature is being increased to 540 °C, and they are attributed to the decomposition of H3btc ligands. No further weight loss occurs until 800 °C indicating an inorganic residuum in the form of metal oxides.Further evaluationof the complex thermal behavior was conducted by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) (Fig. 6). Multiple endo- and exo-thermic effects in the DSC curve matched TGA results. The endothermic peak observed at the temperature region of 80-260 °C is related to the removal of coordinated water molecules, and two exothermic peaks at the temperature region 400-540 °C are attributed to successiveburning of organic parts.Catalysts CharacterizationFT-IR SpectrumThe FT-IR spectra of the silica- and alumina-supported Co-Ni-Zn synthesized catalysts are illustrated in Fig. 7. In the FT-IR spectrum of Co-Ni-Zn/SiO2 catalyst, the broad bond at 3421 cm-1 belongs to the OH stretching mode of physically adsorbed water; in addition, the H-OH bending vibration appears at 1610 cm-1 [31]. The strong band at 909 cm-1 is assigned to the asymmetric stretching mode of Si-O-Si, and the bands observed at 468, 581and 671 cm-1 are imputed to the stretching vibrations of Ni-O, Zn-O and Co-O, respectively [32-34].In the FT-IR spectrum of alumina-supported Co-Ni-Zn catalyst, the OH stretching vibration and the H-OH bending mode of physically adsorbed water appear at 3415 and 1618 cm-1, respectively. The bending vibration of Al-O-Al emerges at 1117 cm-1, and the stretching modes of Ni-O, Zn-O and Co-O appear at 450, 583and 672 cm-1, respectively.X-ray Powder DiffractionThe Co-Ni-Zn catalysts obtained through calcination of inorganic precursors were characterized by X-ray powder diffraction. The X-ray diffractograms of the silica- and alumina-supported Co-Ni-Zn synthesized catalysts have been shown in Fig. 8. The identified phases for both synthesized Co-Ni-Zn catalysts were similar, and contained Ni0.8Zn0.2O and NiO (characteristic peaks for their overlap at 2Ɵ=37.2°, 43.3°, 62.5°, 74.7°, 78.8°), ZnO (characteristic peaks at 2θ=31.9°, 34.7°, 47.5°, 62.5°, 68.7°), ZnCo2O4 (characteristic peaks at 2θ=16.1°, 31.9°, 37.2°, 56.5°, 59.3°, 65.1°, 74.7°), Co3O4 (characteristic peaks at 2θ=31.9°, 37.2°, 56.5°, 59.3°, 65.1°) and NiCo2O4 (characteristic peaks at 2θ=20.9°, 31.9°, 37.2°, 56.5°, 59.3°, 65.1°).The diffractograms of reference catalysts constructed by impregnation method have been illustrated in Fig. 9. Characteristic peaks of NiCo2O4 at 2θ=31.2°, 37.2°, 44.8°, 55.7°, 59.3°, 65.1° are observed; the peaks observed at 2θ=19.1°, 31.2°, 37.2°, 44.8°, 55.7°, 59.3°, 65.1° are related to overlapping of phases Co3O4 and ZnCo2O4.Scanning Electron MicroscopyThe morphology of the synthesized and reference catalysts was investigated by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and their SEM micrographs have been shown in Figs. 10 and 11, respectively. The morphological properties of the synthesized catalysts and those of reference catalysts are different, and they have smaller particle sizes and less agglomeration for the fabricated catalysts.Brunauer-Emmett-TellerTextural properties of the catalysts constructed by thermal decomposition of inorganic precursor and those of the reference catalysts prepared by the impregnation method have been displayed in Table 4. As observed in Table 4, synthesized catalysts have higher surface areas in comparison to reference catalysts. These results were in agreement with the SEM observation which showed the particle sizes of the fabricated catalysts were less than those of the reference catalysts.Transmission Electron MicroscopyThe TEM images of the synthesized and reference catalysts are displayed in Fig. S1. The average crystallite sizes were respectively 15 and 22 nm for the fabricated catalysts with the SiO2 and Al2O3 support, while for the reference catalysts these values were 38 and 40 nm. This result shows that preparation of Co-Ni-Zn catalysts via thermal decomposition of inorganic precursors yields smaller crystallite sizes.Reducibility Studies (H2-TPR)The H2-TPR profiles of the synthesized catalysts have been shown in Fig. S2. The reduction peak observed in the range of 300-420 °C corresponds to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO, NiCo2O4 to NiCoO2 and NiO to Ni. At this temperature region, Co3+ and Zn2+ of ZnCoO4 phase were reduced to Co2+ and Zn0, respectively. For the NiCoO2, the broad peak at 420-635 °C is assigned to co-reduction of Co2+ to Co0 and Ni2+ to Ni0, Additionally, the reduction of CoO to Co0 occurred at the same temperature range. The reduction peak around 660 °C corresponds to the reduction of ZnO to Zn0 [35-42].The H2-TPR profiles of both reference catalysts reveal multiple overlapping peaks because of different reduction steps (Fig. S3). It can be seen that both reference catalysts have the same reduction peaks at 300 to 400 °C and 400-700 °C, and this is related to the reduction of Co3O4, NiCo2O4 and ZnCoO4 phases, like synthesized catalysts. According to TPR and XRD results, one point that makes synthesized catalysts different from reference catalysts is the existence of NiO and ZnO phases in the synthesized catalysts. In fact, these phases serve as promoters in the catalysts. The ZnO phase reduces cobalt-support interaction and affects cobalt reducibility; furthermore, the NiO phase amplifies the hydrogen adsorption. Hence, these phases affect catalyst activity and improve the catalytic activity of synthesized catalysts.Catalytic PerformanceHydrogenation of carbon monoxide at the presence of the synthesized and reference catalysts was conducted at the atmospheric pressureat the temperature range 200-300 °C with H2/CO ratio of 2.As shown in Fig. 12, the CO conversion of the catalysts increases with the temperature, and the CO conversion of the synthesized Co-Ni-Zn/SiO2 and -Al2O3 catalysts is higher in comparison to the reference catalysts at all studied temperatures.The catalytic performance of the catalysts that is prepared by different procedures grows with an increase in temperature from 200 to 300 °C (Figs. 13, 14). While the selectivity to the olefin and paraffin is reduced with an increase in temperature, the methane selectivities of both constructed and reference catalysts grow. The results revealed that the optimal operating temperature of the catalysts is 260 °C. At this temperature, the Co-Ni-Zn/SiO2 and Co-Ni-Zn/Al2O3 synthesized catalysts, prepared by thermal decomposition of inorganic precursor, have higher selectivity to light olefin products and lower methane selectivity. Moreover, the paraffin selectivity is favorable at the optimum temperature. Selectivity to C2H4 is 46% and 40% for silica and alumina supported, respectively. In addition, propylene selectivity of synthesized catalysts is about 16%. The selectivity into paraffin (C2-C3) of synthesized catalyst obtains about 19% and 17% for silica and alumina supported, respectively. As the data show, the synthesized catalysts have acceptable activity in FT reaction due to the catalyst physicochemical features. It can be seen that from SEM results of synthesized catalysts, these catalysts have low degree of agglomeration and small particle sizes, which is in good agreement with the results obtained from XRD. Moreover, the synthesized catalysts have high surface area. According to the explained catalysts feature, it can be concluded that the catalyst physicochemical features affect the catalysts activity. Comparing both synthesized catalysts, it can be concluded that the catalytic performance of Co-Ni-Zn/SiO2 is slightly better than alumina-supported Co-Ni-Zn catalyst. On the other hand, in both reference catalysts, methane selectivity is higher compared to the fabricated catalysts, and the production amount of olefins and paraffins is lower. All these data reveal that catalysts production through thermal decomposition of inorganic precursors based on complex 1 is a promising procedure due to good active phase dispersion, small particle size, low degree of agglomeration and formation of promoter phases.Stability TestThe stability (Fig. 15) of the constructed catalysts was studied at 260 °C, and that of the reference catalysts was evaluated at 300 °C because they display the maximum CO conversion at this temperature. The catalysts prepared by thermal decomposition were stable for 10 h atoptimal operating temperature (260 °C). The stability test of the constructed catalysts was continued for 30 h, and only a slight decrease in the activity of the catalysts was observed. The activity of the reference catalysts was relatively constant for 7 h, and during the following 30 h, the activity decreased faster than for the synthesized catalysts.ConclusionThe Co-Ni-Zn mixed metal catalysts were produced by thermal decomposition of their inorganic precursors and were compared with the reference catalysts prepared by the impregnation method. The different preparation procedure causes smaller particle size, higher surface area and lower agglomeration of the catalysts fabricated by thermal decomposition. The catalytic performance tests of both types of catalysts were carried out at the temperature range 200-300 °C with H2:CO ratio of 2:1. The results show higher selectivity to desirable products and better stability for the fabricated catalysts.AcknowledgmentsThe authors are grateful to University of Sistan and Bluchestan for the support of this work. elements.content: A hydrothermal technique was employed in order to produce a novel coordination polymer [Co0.42Ni0.40Zn0.68(btc)(H2O)6] (1). The complex (1) was characterized by elemental analysis, and FT-IR spectroscopy; and its structure was determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD). Alumina-supported Co–Ni–Zn and silica catalysts were prepared by thermal decomposition of respective inorganic precursors (fabricated or synthesized catalysts) and through impregnation method as reference catalysts. The evaluation of catalytic activity of these catalysts was carried out at a fixed bed reactor for Fischer–Tropsch synthesis. The performance of the synthesized catalysts was much better than the catalysts which were produced by the impregnation procedure, those that were characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), XRD, and BET specific surface area.
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A hydrothermal technique was employed in order to produce a novel coordination polymer [Co0.42Ni0.40Zn0.68(btc)(H2O)6] (1). The complex (1) was characterized by elemental analysis, and FT-IR spectroscopy; and its structure was determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD). Alumina-supported Co-Ni-Zn and silica catalysts were prepared by thermal decomposition of respective inorganic precursors (fabricated or synthesized catalysts) and through impregnation method as reference catalysts. The evaluation of catalytic activity of these catalysts was carried out at a fixed bed reactor for Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. The performance of the synthesized catalysts was much better than the catalysts which were produced by the impregnation procedure, those that were characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), XRD, and BET specific surface area.

elements.content:
Introduction

Fischer–Tropsch synthesis (FTS) is a catalytic polymerization reaction through which clean fuels can be produced from natural gas, biomass and coal [1–3]. Catalysts based on cobalt, nickel, iron and ruthenium are considered efficient compounds for hydrogenation of carbon monoxide [4–6] despite the fact that group VIII transition metals catalyze the FTS.
elements.clean_text:
Graphical Abstract



Introduction

Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) is a catalytic polymerization reaction through which clean fuels can be produced from natural gas, biomass and coal [1-3]. Catalysts based on cobalt, nickel, iron and ruthenium are considered efficient compounds for hydrogenation of carbon monoxide [4-6] despite the fact that group VIII transition metals catalyze the FTS.

elements.content: Owing to their low water–gas shift activity, long life and high selectivity into aliphatic hydrocarbons [7, 8], cobalt-based catalysts are particularly useful for the FTS. Promoters have a number of advantages for Co-based catalysts in the FTS; for example, Rytter et al. [9] found that nickel deeply affects the catalytic activity and can be used as a promoter of reduction and activity (with loading > 5 wt%). Ishihara et al. [10, 11] proved that an alloy of cobalt and nickel reinforces hydrogen adsorption, and leads to an increase in the catalytic activity. With regard to these results and other investigations [12, 13], nickel can be employed as a promoter in FTS. In addition, another possible promoter for cobalt-based catalysts is zinc, which can reduce cobalt–support interaction, thereby affecting cobalt reducibility [14, 15].

Promoters have a number of advantages for Co-based catalysts in the FTS; for example, Rytter et al. [9] found that nickel deeply affects the catalytic activity and can be used as a promoter of reduction and activity (with loading>5 wt%). Ishihara et al. [10, 11] proved that an alloy of cobalt and nickel reinforces hydrogen adsorption, and leads to an increase in the catalytic activity. With regard to these results and other investigations [12, 13], nickel can be employed as a promoter in FTS. In addition, another possible promoter for cobalt-based catalysts is zinc, which can reduce cobalt-support interaction, thereby affecting cobalt reducibility [14, 15].

elements.content: The design of synthetic procedures for catalysts that are suitable for FTS is technologically very important. An appropriate method used in applying inorganic complexes to produce mixed metal oxides exhibits some advantages such as smaller particle sizes, higher surface area and homogenous dispersion of metals [16–21]. In this work, a new inorganic complex [Co0.42Ni0.40Zn0.68(btc)(H2O)6] was prepared and the complex was used for the fabrication of inorganic precursors. Then, the mixed metal oxides resulting from thermal decomposition of inorganic precursors were evaluated for catalytic activity in FTS, and were compared with reference catalysts which were generated by the impregnation procedure; and the physicochemical characterizations were determined by Brunauer–Emmett–Teller method (BET), X-ray diffraction (XRD) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM).

elements.content: All purchased chemicals and solvents were of reagent grade and were used without further purification; elemental analyses were carried out by using a Leco, CHNS-932 elemental analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were measured with Perkin Elmer (spectrum two) spectrophotometer as KBr disks in the 4000–400 cm−1 range, and simultaneous thermal analysis (STA) was made by usingRheometric Scientific ARES, at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. Powder diffraction data were recorded on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE the 2θ range from 10° to 80°, and the morphology of the catalysts was studied on MIRA3 TESCANFE SEM,operatingwith an accelerating voltage of 15 kV. The BET surface areas of the samples were measured by N2 physi-sorption using anASAP 2020 apparatus. Each sample was degassed under nitrogen atmosphere at 350 °C for 4 h. The images were recorded with transmission electron microscope (TEM) Philips CM120 with a LaB6 cathode at acceleration voltage 120 kV. TEM is equipped with a CCD camera Olympus Veleta. Powdered samples were prepared by dispersing in water under ultrasonic treatment. Drop of suspension was evaporated on cooper grid with carbon film. H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were carried out using a NanoSORD NS91 (made by Sensiran Co., Iran) apparatus. H2-TPR experiments were conducted on 50 mg of each catalyst placed in a U-shaped quartz reactor. Prior to each TPR run, the catalyst was degassed in a flow of 10 sccmAr at 300 °C for 1 h, and it was cooled down to room temperature under the same atmosphere. The sample was then reduced by 10 sccm of 5.0% H2/Ar mixture while the temperature was raised to 900 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1.

Experimental

Materials and Instruments

All purchased chemicals and solvents were of reagent grade and were used without further purification; elemental analyses were carried out by using a Leco, CHNS-932 elemental analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were measured with Perkin Elmer (spectrum two) spectrophotometer as KBr disks in the 4000-400 cm-1 range, and simultaneous thermal analysis (STA) was made by usingRheometric Scientific ARES, at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. Powder diffraction data were recorded on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE the 2θ range from 10° to 80°, and the morphology of the catalysts was studied on MIRA3 TESCANFE SEM,operatingwith an accelerating voltage of 15 kV. The BET surface areas of the samples were measured by N2 physi-sorption using anASAP 2020 apparatus. Each sample was degassed under nitrogen atmosphere at 350 °C for 4 h. The images were recorded with transmission electron microscope (TEM) Philips CM120 with a LaB6 cathode at acceleration voltage 120 kV. TEM is equipped with a CCD camera Olympus Veleta. Powdered samples were prepared by dispersing in water under ultrasonic treatment. Drop of suspension was evaporated on cooper grid with carbon film. H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were carried out using a NanoSORD NS91 (made by Sensiran Co., Iran) apparatus. H2-TPR experiments were conducted on 50 mg of each catalyst placed in a U-shaped quartz reactor. Prior to each TPR run, the catalyst was degassed in a flow of 10 sccmAr at 300 °C for 1 h, and it was cooled down to room temperature under the same atmosphere. The sample was then reduced by 10 sccm of 5.0% H2/Ar mixture while the temperature was raised to 900 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1.

elements.content: 1,3,5-Benzenetricarboxylic acid (105 mg, 0.5 mmol) was dissolved in 10 ml of distilled water, followed by addition of NaOH (40 mg, 1 mmol). Then it was stirred 30 min at room temperature. An aqueous solution of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (291 mg, 1.0 mmol), Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O (290 mg, 1 mmol) and Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (297 mg, 1.0 mmol) was appended to the above-mentioned solution and was stirred 30 min at room temperature. The resulting solution was placed in a Parr-Teflon lined stainless steel vessel. It was sealed and heated to 130 °C for 3 days and then cooled to the room temperature. Colorless crystals of 1 were obtained by filtration and they were dried in air. The yield was 75%. Anal. Calc. for C9H15Co0.42Ni0.40O12.06Zn0.68: C, 8.01; H, 1.12. Found: C, 8.04; H, 1.08%.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Complex 1

1,3,5-Benzenetricarboxylic acid (105 mg, 0.5 mmol) was dissolved in 10 ml of distilled water, followed by addition of NaOH (40 mg, 1 mmol). Then it was stirred 30 min at room temperature. An aqueous solution of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (291 mg, 1.0 mmol), Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O (290 mg, 1 mmol) and Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (297 mg, 1.0 mmol) was appended to the above-mentioned solution and was stirred 30 min at room temperature. The resulting solution was placed in a Parr-Teflon lined stainless steel vessel. It was sealed and heated to 130 °C for 3 days and then cooled to the room temperature. Colorless crystals of 1 were obtained by filtration and they were dried in air. The yield was 75%. Anal. Calc. for C9H15Co0.42Ni0.40O12.06Zn0.68: C, 8.01; H, 1.12. Found: C, 8.04; H, 1.08%.

elements.content: Single crystal of approximate dimensions 0.04 × 0.06 × 0.37 mm for complex 1 was used for the determination of crystal structure on SuperNova diffractometer equipped with mirror monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). A total of 11,665 reflections were collected in the range of 3.39°<θ < 29.71° at 95 (10) K, of which 3363 independent ones [R(int) = 0.0206] were used. The crystal structure was solved by direct methods with the Superflip program [22] and was refined by full-matrix least squares on F2 using the program Jana 2006 [23]. All hydrogen atoms present in the structure model were discernible in difference Fourier maps and could be refined to reasonable geometry; nevertheless, hydrogen atoms attached to carbon were constraint at geometrically expected positions. Positions of water hydrogen atoms were refined using an O–H bond restraint 0.88 Å with s.u. 0.001, and H–O–H angle restraint 105° with s.u. 1.0. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined using harmonic refinement, while for hydrogen atoms isotropic ADPs were used with Uiso(H) = 1.2Ueq(C, O). The crystallographic dataare summarized in Table 1.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Structure Determination

Single crystal of approximate dimensions 0.04×0.06×0.37 mm for complex 1 was used for the determination of crystal structure on SuperNova diffractometer equipped with mirror monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ=0.71073 Å). A total of 11,665 reflections were collected in the range of 3.39°<θ<29.71° at 95 (10) K, of which 3363 independent ones [R(int)=0.0206] were used. The crystal structure was solved by direct methods with the Superflip program [22] and was refined by full-matrix least squares on F2 using the program Jana 2006 [23]. All hydrogen atoms present in the structure model were discernible in difference Fourier maps and could be refined to reasonable geometry; nevertheless, hydrogen atoms attached to carbon were constraint at geometrically expected positions. Positions of water hydrogen atoms were refined using an O-H bond restraint 0.88 Å with s.u. 0.001, and H-O-H angle restraint 105° with s.u. 1.0. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined using harmonic refinement, while for hydrogen atoms isotropic ADPs were used with Uiso(H)=1.2Ueq(C, O). The crystallographic dataare summarized in Table 1.

elements.content: The mixed site disorder was observed in the structure, and the coordinates and ADPs of the mixed site atoms were made equal. Since the refinement of the metal ratios was not possible due to the electronic similarities of three present metals, the ratio determined by microprobe analysis was used instead, and because the structure crystallized in non-centrosymmetric space group, the Flack parameter was refined with a resulting value of 0.460 (8).

Preparation of Reference Catalysts

The silica- or alumina-supported Co–Ni–Zn reference catalysts werepreparedusing the impregnation method. The support (silica or alumina) wasimpregnated by using an aqueous solution consisting of nickel nitrate, cobalt nitrate and zinc nitrate. The suspension was stirred and heated at 60 °C in a rota-evaporator and it was kept at this temperature for 5 h. After that, the resulting mixture was filtrated and dried in an oven at 120 °C for 12 h, and the precursor was calcined at 600 °C for 5 h.

Preparation of Reference Catalysts

The silica- or alumina-supported Co-Ni-Zn reference catalysts werepreparedusing the impregnation method. The support (silica or alumina) wasimpregnated by using an aqueous solution consisting of nickel nitrate, cobalt nitrate and zinc nitrate. The suspension was stirred and heated at 60 °C in a rota-evaporator and it was kept at this temperature for 5 h. After that, the resulting mixture was filtrated and dried in an oven at 120 °C for 12 h, and the precursor was calcined at 600 °C for 5 h.

elements.content: The catalytic performances of the catalysts for the Fischer–Tropsch reaction were carried out in a fixed bed micro reactor operating at the atmospheric pressure. The reactor tube was made of stainless steel with an internal diameter of 1.7 cm. In each run, 0.8 g of the catalyst was loaded to the reactor and reduced in a mixture of hydrogen/nitrogen gas (with a flow rate of 30 mL min−1 for each gas) at 400 °C for 8 h. The N2/H2 was then replaced for the synthesis gas H2/CO (2:1), and the Fischer–Tropsch reaction was carried out at the temperature range of 200–300 °C and GHSV = 2700 h−1. The gas chromatograph (Thermo ONIX UNICAM PROGC+), equipped with sample loop, two thermal conductivity detectors (TCD) and one flame ionization detector (FID), was employed for online analysis of the reactant and product streams. The TCD was used for the analysis of H2 and CO, and the analysis of hydrocarbons was carried out by FID. The contents of the sample loop were automatically injected into a capillary column, and each run of GC analysis lasted more than 30 min. Results and DiscussionCharacterization of the ComplexCrystal Structure

The complex 1, which is a coordination polymer with two symmetry-distinct mixed-sites metal centers containing cobalt(II), nickel(II) and zinc(II) cations,crystalizes in the monoclinic system with the non-centrosymmetric space group C2. As shown in Fig. 1, four oxygen atoms from water molecules and two oxygen atoms from carboxylate groups surround each metal center .The Co(II), Ni(II) and Zn(II) ions are six-coordinated in a distorted octahedral geometry, and all bond distances and bond angles correspond well with values found in other cobalt(II), nickel(II) and zinc(II) complexes [24–26]. Selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in Table 2.

Results and Discussion

Characterization of the Complex

Crystal Structure

The complex 1, which is a coordination polymer with two symmetry-distinct mixed-sites metal centers containing cobalt(II), nickel(II) and zinc(II) cations,crystalizes in the monoclinic system with the non-centrosymmetric space group C2. As shown in Fig. 1, four oxygen atoms from water molecules and two oxygen atoms from carboxylate groups surround each metal center .The Co(II), Ni(II) and Zn(II) ions are six-coordinated in a distorted octahedral geometry, and all bond distances and bond angles correspond well with values found in other cobalt(II), nickel(II) and zinc(II) complexes [24-26]. Selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in Table 2.

elements.content: Several inter-molecular and intra-molecular hydrogen bonds stabilize the crystal structure (Fig. 2). The coordinated water molecules act as donors in hydrogen bonds, whereas oxygen atoms of carboxylate groups and those of other water molecules are used as the acceptors of the bond. For further details on hydrogen bonding, refer to Table 3.

FT-IR Spectrum

The FT-IR spectrum of 1 (Fig. 5) displays a broad band at 3456 cm−1 which is assigned to the stretching vibrations of the coordinated water molecules. The strong band which is observed at 1615 cm−1 is the result of deprotonation of carboxyl groups [27, 28], and the band at 3195 cm−1 is assigned to C–H stretching vibration of the benzene ring [29]. Lack of vibrations at the 1700 cm−1 indicates that the carboxylic groups are fully deprotonated. The anti-symmetric νa(COO) stretching vibrations of the carboxylate groups appear at 1522 and 1472 cm−1, while the symmetric stretching, νs(COO), emerges at 1372 and 1434 cm−1. The frequency differences (Δν\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$${\Delta }{\upnu }$$\end{document}) are 150 and 38 cm−1 indicating the presence of monodentate and bidentate coordination mode of the carboxylate groups to the metallic centers, respectively [30]. The band which appears at 719 cm−1 belongs to the δ(COO) vibration.

Thermal Analysis

The thermal stability of complex 1 was investigated by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), Fig. 6. Two weight losses at the temperature region of 80–260 °C are brought about by eliminating the water molecules, with a total weight loss of about 26.6%\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\%$$\end{document} (calcd. 26.4%\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\%$$\end{document}). The two ultimate steps of weight losses occur while the temperature is being increased to 540 °C, and they are attributed to the decomposition of H3btc ligands. No further weight loss occurs until 800 °C indicating an inorganic residuum in the form of metal oxides.

elements.content: Further evaluationof the complex thermal behavior was conducted by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) (Fig. 6). Multiple endo- and exo-thermic effects in the DSC curve matched TGA results. The endothermic peak observed at the temperature region of 80–260 °C is related to the removal of coordinated water molecules, and two exothermic peaks at the temperature region 400–540 °C are attributed to successiveburning of organic parts.

elements.content: The FT-IR spectra of the silica- and alumina-supported Co–Ni–Zn synthesized catalysts are illustrated in Fig. 7. In the FT-IR spectrum of Co–Ni–Zn/SiO2 catalyst, the broad bond at 3421 cm−1 belongs to the OH stretching mode of physically adsorbed water; in addition, the H–OH bending vibration appears at 1610 cm−1 [31]. The strong band at 909 cm−1 is assigned to the asymmetric stretching mode of Si–O–Si, and the bands observed at 468, 581and 671 cm−1 are imputed to the stretching vibrations of Ni–O, Zn–O and Co–O, respectively [32–34].

The FT-IR spectra of the silica- and alumina-supported Co-Ni-Zn synthesized catalysts are illustrated in Fig. 7. In the FT-IR spectrum of Co-Ni-Zn/SiO2 catalyst, the broad bond at 3421 cm-1 belongs to the OH stretching mode of physically adsorbed water; in addition, the H-OH bending vibration appears at 1610 cm-1 [31]. The strong band at 909 cm-1 is assigned to the asymmetric stretching mode of Si-O-Si, and the bands observed at 468, 581and 671 cm-1 are imputed to the stretching vibrations of Ni-O, Zn-O and Co-O, respectively [32-34].

elements.content: The Co–Ni–Zn catalysts obtained through calcination of inorganic precursors were characterized by X-ray powder diffraction. The X-ray diffractograms of the silica- and alumina-supported Co–Ni–Zn synthesized catalysts have been shown in Fig. 8. The identified phases for both synthesized Co–Ni–Zn catalysts were similar, and contained Ni0.8Zn0.2O and NiO (characteristic peaks for their overlap at 2Ɵ = 37.2°, 43.3°, 62.5°, 74.7°, 78.8°), ZnO (characteristic peaks at 2θ = 31.9°, 34.7°, 47.5°, 62.5°, 68.7°), ZnCo2O4 (characteristic peaks at 2θ = 16.1°, 31.9°, 37.2°, 56.5°, 59.3°, 65.1°, 74.7°), Co3O4 (characteristic peaks at 2θ = 31.9°, 37.2°, 56.5°, 59.3°, 65.1°) and NiCo2O4 (characteristic peaks at 2θ = 20.9°, 31.9°, 37.2°, 56.5°, 59.3°, 65.1°).
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Powder Diffraction

The Co-Ni-Zn catalysts obtained through calcination of inorganic precursors were characterized by X-ray powder diffraction. The X-ray diffractograms of the silica- and alumina-supported Co-Ni-Zn synthesized catalysts have been shown in Fig. 8. The identified phases for both synthesized Co-Ni-Zn catalysts were similar, and contained Ni0.8Zn0.2O and NiO (characteristic peaks for their overlap at 2Ɵ=37.2°, 43.3°, 62.5°, 74.7°, 78.8°), ZnO (characteristic peaks at 2θ=31.9°, 34.7°, 47.5°, 62.5°, 68.7°), ZnCo2O4 (characteristic peaks at 2θ=16.1°, 31.9°, 37.2°, 56.5°, 59.3°, 65.1°, 74.7°), Co3O4 (characteristic peaks at 2θ=31.9°, 37.2°, 56.5°, 59.3°, 65.1°) and NiCo2O4 (characteristic peaks at 2θ=20.9°, 31.9°, 37.2°, 56.5°, 59.3°, 65.1°).

The H2-TPR profiles of the synthesized catalysts have been shown in Fig. S2. The reduction peak observed in the range of 300–420 °C corresponds to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO, NiCo2O4 to NiCoO2 and NiO to Ni. At this temperature region, Co3+ and Zn2+ of ZnCoO4 phase were reduced to Co2+ and Zn0, respectively. For the NiCoO2, the broad peak at 420–635 °C is assigned to co-reduction of Co2+ to Co0 and Ni2+ to Ni0, Additionally, the reduction of CoO to Co0 occurred at the same temperature range. The reduction peak around 660 °C corresponds to the reduction of ZnO to Zn0 [35–42].

Reducibility Studies (H2-TPR)

The H2-TPR profiles of the synthesized catalysts have been shown in Fig. S2. The reduction peak observed in the range of 300-420 °C corresponds to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO, NiCo2O4 to NiCoO2 and NiO to Ni. At this temperature region, Co3+ and Zn2+ of ZnCoO4 phase were reduced to Co2+ and Zn0, respectively. For the NiCoO2, the broad peak at 420-635 °C is assigned to co-reduction of Co2+ to Co0 and Ni2+ to Ni0, Additionally, the reduction of CoO to Co0 occurred at the same temperature range. The reduction peak around 660 °C corresponds to the reduction of ZnO to Zn0 [35-42].

elements.content: The H2-TPR profiles of both reference catalysts reveal multiple overlapping peaks because of different reduction steps (Fig. S3). It can be seen that both reference catalysts have the same reduction peaks at 300 to 400 °C and 400–700 °C, and this is related to the reduction of Co3O4, NiCo2O4 and ZnCoO4 phases, like synthesized catalysts. According to TPR and XRD results, one point that makes synthesized catalysts different from reference catalysts is the existence of NiO and ZnO phases in the synthesized catalysts. In fact, these phases serve as promoters in the catalysts. The ZnO phase reduces cobalt-support interaction and affects cobalt reducibility; furthermore, the NiO phase amplifies the hydrogen adsorption. Hence, these phases affect catalyst activity and improve the catalytic activity of synthesized catalysts.

Hydrogenation of carbon monoxide at the presence of the synthesized and reference catalysts was conducted at the atmospheric pressureat the temperature range 200–300 °C with H2/CO ratio of 2.

As shown in Fig. 12, the CO conversion of the catalysts increases with the temperature, and the CO conversion of the synthesized Co–Ni–Zn/SiO2 and –Al2O3 catalysts is higher in comparison to the reference catalysts at all studied temperatures.
elements.clean_text:
Catalytic Performance

Hydrogenation of carbon monoxide at the presence of the synthesized and reference catalysts was conducted at the atmospheric pressureat the temperature range 200-300 °C with H2/CO ratio of 2.

As shown in Fig. 12, the CO conversion of the catalysts increases with the temperature, and the CO conversion of the synthesized Co-Ni-Zn/SiO2 and -Al2O3 catalysts is higher in comparison to the reference catalysts at all studied temperatures.

elements.content: The catalytic performance of the catalysts that is prepared by different procedures grows with an increase in temperature from 200 to 300 °C (Figs. 13, 14). While the selectivity to the olefin and paraffin is reduced with an increase in temperature, the methane selectivities of both constructed and reference catalysts grow. The results revealed that the optimal operating temperature of the catalysts is 260 °C. At this temperature, the Co–Ni–Zn/SiO2 and Co–Ni–Zn/Al2O3 synthesized catalysts, prepared by thermal decomposition of inorganic precursor, have higher selectivity to light olefin products and lower methane selectivity. Moreover, the paraffin selectivity is favorable at the optimum temperature. Selectivity to C2H4 is 46% and 40% for silica and alumina supported, respectively. In addition, propylene selectivity of synthesized catalysts is about 16%. The selectivity into paraffin (C2–C3) of synthesized catalyst obtains about 19% and 17% for silica and alumina supported, respectively. As the data show, the synthesized catalysts have acceptable activity in FT reaction due to the catalyst physicochemical features. It can be seen that from SEM results of synthesized catalysts, these catalysts have low degree of agglomeration and small particle sizes, which is in good agreement with the results obtained from XRD. Moreover, the synthesized catalysts have high surface area. According to the explained catalysts feature, it can be concluded that the catalyst physicochemical features affect the catalysts activity. Comparing both synthesized catalysts, it can be concluded that the catalytic performance of Co–Ni–Zn/SiO2 is slightly better than alumina-supported Co–Ni–Zn catalyst. On the other hand, in both reference catalysts, methane selectivity is higher compared to the fabricated catalysts, and the production amount of olefins and paraffins is lower. All these data reveal that catalysts production through thermal decomposition of inorganic precursors based on complex 1 is a promising procedure due to good active phase dispersion, small particle size, low degree of agglomeration and formation of promoter phases.

elements.content:
Stability Test

The stability (Fig. 15) of the constructed catalysts was studied at 260 °C, and that of the reference catalysts was evaluated at 300 °C because they display the maximum CO conversion at this temperature. The catalysts prepared by thermal decomposition were stable for 10 h atoptimal operating temperature (260 °C). The stability test of the constructed catalysts was continued for 30 h, and only a slight decrease in the activity of the catalysts was observed. The activity of the reference catalysts was relatively constant for 7 h, and during the following 30 h, the activity decreased faster than for the synthesized catalysts.

elements.content:
Conclusion

The Co–Ni–Zn mixed metal catalysts were produced by thermal decomposition of their inorganic precursors and were compared with the reference catalysts prepared by the impregnation method. The different preparation procedure causes smaller particle size, higher surface area and lower agglomeration of the catalysts fabricated by thermal decomposition. The catalytic performance tests of both types of catalysts were carried out at the temperature range 200–300 °C with H2:CO ratio of 2:1. The results show higher selectivity to desirable products and better stability for the fabricated catalysts.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The Co-Ni-Zn mixed metal catalysts were produced by thermal decomposition of their inorganic precursors and were compared with the reference catalysts prepared by the impregnation method. The different preparation procedure causes smaller particle size, higher surface area and lower agglomeration of the catalysts fabricated by thermal decomposition. The catalytic performance tests of both types of catalysts were carried out at the temperature range 200-300 °C with H2:CO ratio of 2:1. The results show higher selectivity to desirable products and better stability for the fabricated catalysts.

1,3,5-Benzenetricarboxylic acid (105 mg, 0.5 mmol) was dissolved in 10 ml of distilled water, followed by addition of NaOH (40 mg, 1 mmol). Then it was stirred 30 min at room temperature. An aqueous solution of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (291 mg, 1.0 mmol), Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O (290 mg, 1 mmol) and Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (297 mg, 1.0 mmol) was appended to the above-mentioned solution and was stirred 30 min at room temperature. The resulting solution was placed in a Parr-Teflon lined stainless steel vessel. It was sealed and heated to 130 °C for 3 days and then cooled to the room temperature. Colorless crystals of 1 were obtained by filtration and they were dried in air. The yield was 75%. Anal. Calc. for C9H15Co0.42Ni0.40O12.06Zn0.68: C, 8.01; H, 1.12. Found: C, 8.04; H, 1.08%.

Synthesis of [Co<sub>0.42</sub>Ni<sub>0.40</sub>Zn<sub>0.68</sub> (btc)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>6</sub>]/SiO<sub>2</sub> Precursor

To prepare [Co0.42Ni0.40Zn0.68 (btc)(H2O)6]/SiO2 precursor, 0.6 g silica was added to an aqueous solution containing 5.2 g of the complex 1. The mixture was stirred and evaporated at 60 °C in a rota-evaporator for 5 h. The resulting precipitate was filtrated and then it was dried in an oven at 120 °C for 12 h.

Synthesis of [Co<sub>0.42</sub>Ni<sub>0.40</sub>Zn<sub>0.68</sub> (btc)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>6</sub>]/Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> Precursor

The [Co0.42Ni0.40Zn0.68 (btc)(H2O)6]/Al2O3 precursor was obtained by mixing 0.6 g of alumina with an aqueous solution containing 5.2 g of the complex 1. The suspension was stirred and aged at 60 °C in a rota-evaporator for 5 h. The final mixture was filtrated and dried in an oven at 120 °C for 12 h.

Synthesis of Alumina-Supported Cobalt–Nickel–Zinc Catalyst, Co–Ni–Zn/Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>

The [Co0.42Ni0.40Zn0.68 (btc)(H2O)6]/Al2O3 was calcined at 600 °C in an electric furnaceat the atmosphere of static air for 6 h.

Preparation of Reference Catalysts

The silica- or alumina-supported Co–Ni–Zn reference catalysts werepreparedusing the impregnation method. The support (silica or alumina) wasimpregnated by using an aqueous solution consisting of nickel nitrate, cobalt nitrate and zinc nitrate. The suspension was stirred and heated at 60 °C in a rota-evaporator and it was kept at this temperature for 5 h. After that, the resulting mixture was filtrated and dried in an oven at 120 °C for 12 h, and the precursor was calcined at 600 °C for 5 h.
